title: Anthony van Ryneveld
text:
Anthony John van Ryneveld (7 November 1925 – 29 August 2018) was a <a href="South%20African%20people">South African</a> first-class <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er.
The son of Reginald Clive Berrangè van Ryneveld and Maria Alfreda Blanckenberg, he was born at <a href="Plumstead%2C%20Cape%20Town">Plumstead</a> in <a href="Cape%20Town">Cape Town</a> in November 1925. He was educated at the <a href="Diocesan%20College">Diocesan College</a>, before going up to <a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Oxford">Trinity College, Oxford</a> as a <a href="Rhodes%20Scholarship">Rhodes Scholar</a>. While studying at Oxford, he made a single appearance in <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for <a href="Oxford%20University%20Cricket%20Club">Oxford University</a> against the <a href="Free%20Foresters%20Cricket%20Club">Free Foresters</a> at <a href="University_Parks%23Cricket_ground">Oxford</a> in 1947. Batting twice in the match, he was dismissed for 50 runs in the Oxford first innings by <a href="Ian%20Peebles">Ian Peebles</a>, while in their second innings he was dismissed for 19 runs by <a href="Sir%20John%20Brocklebank%2C%205th%20Baronet">John Brocklebank</a>. 
He was better known in South Africa as a <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player. van Ryneveld was in business and served on the Old Diocesan Union Committee. He died at <a href="Tokai%2C%20Cape%20Town">Tokai</a> in Cape Town, three weeks after being diagnosed with cancer. Both his brother <a href="Clive%20van%20Ryneveld">Clive</a> and uncle <a href="Jimmy%20Blanckenberg">Jimmy Blanckenberg</a> played <a href="Test%20cricket">Test cricket</a> for <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20cricket%20team">South Africa</a>. Another uncle, <a href="Stewart%20West%20%28cricketer%29">Stewart West</a>, was also a first-class cricketer.
